executive_summary: Over the past five years, the Hair Salons industry has benefited from rising consumer sentiment and per capita disposable income. These trends have also increased demand for ancillary services to standard haircuts like hair modification treatments (e.g. straightening procedures, perms and relaxing treatments), skincare services and others. Nonetheless, the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 led to the temporary closure of industry establishments and a significant decline in demand in 2020 as individuals had fewer reasons to get haircuts due to stay-at-home mandates and high unemployment. These economic trends caused revenue to decline at a CAGR of 1.5% to an estimated $52.2 billion over the past five years, while inching upward an anticipated 0.2% in 2023.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Devastating Economic Effects of the COVID-19 Pandemic Harm Industry Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Despite the extended closures of industry establishments in 2020 during the COVID-19 pandemic, hair salons adapted to evolving consumer trends and maximized consumer output during large-scale economic volatility. Many companies and stylists leveraged online platforms like Instagram and Facebook as a cost-effective way to attract clientele. Many salons have also turned to mobile applications, like MyTime, to streamline the appointment booking process and provide a convenient way for clients to schedule appointments. Additionally, hair salons have been extending their product and service offerings to appeal to diversified demographics and niche markets. Nonetheless, profit declined during the five-year period, with the average profit margin reaching 5.0% of revenue in 2023.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: A core factor in the industry's success is rising per capita disposable income
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Particularly since haircuts and broader hair services are considered discretionary goods in the eyes of consumers. As the pandemic crushed economic stability, per capita disposable income fell, resulting in a pullback of consumer demand for hair salon services.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Innovation in Hair Products and Services Dampens Negative Economic Impact on the Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: A core development over the past five years that boosted hair salons is the implementation of new hair products and care services that diversified the industry's revenue stream and provided hair salons with diversification of client services. With the COVID-19 pandemic devastating the economy, many hair salons adopted alternative services, like hair coloring and skincare services, which are more expensive and target a niche consumer base.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Acceleration of Technology Use Strengthens Hair Salons' Customer Relations Strategy
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The industry's expansion into social media and online servicing continues to strengthen its customer relations strategy and improve service convenience. Many hair salons expanded their online footprint into social media sites like Instagram and Facebook to capture consumers' interest online while also receiving a direct-to-consumer tool that they can leverage.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Growing Adoption of Sustainability Standards Enhances Hair Salons' Product Quality
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: With many larger companies and industries continuing to emphasize the use of sustainable items in their product stream, hair salons have continued embracing the latest trends in sustainable shampoos and beauty products in an attempt to improve their environmental footprint. By incorporating organic produce within core products such as shampoos, not only will operators bolster sustainability efforts, but also provide quality hair products when conducting haircuts and styling services that require a customer's hair to be washed.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Improving Economic Situation Accelerates Industry Recovery
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: With the COVID-19 pandemic decimating the broader economy and hair salons enduring widespread losses in 2020, the economic recovery following the pandemic will bolster consumers' income levels and accelerate the industry's recovery.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Favorable Population Trends Will Boost Consumer Stream
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The dependence of hair salons in acquiring new customers lies within broader population trends across the United States, as operators will look to take advantage of consumer demand shifts in an effort to capture a niche market.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Evolving Industry Trends Must Be Monitored
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: To ensure maximum competitiveness in a fragmented industry, hair salons must stay on top of the latest hairstyle trends to capture new consumer niches and maintain a competitive market presence.

A new point of emphasis across industry trends is the growth of the male markets, with increased self-care consciousness from the male population providing hair salons with an expansive demographic they can target and acquire.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Adoption of New Technology Will Provide Streamlined Service
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Hair salon operators will continue to push for innovation in communication solutions in an attempt to expand their customer base and strengthen new customer outreach.

industry_definition: This industry includes salons that primarily offer hair-care services such as haircutting, hair coloring and hairstyling. Additionally, these companies may provide facials and makeup applications (except permanent makeup) and retail beauty products. This industry does not include operators that primarily offer training in barbering or hairstyling.

negative_impact_factors: Low - Steady Barriers To Entry Level

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - Per capita disposable income
threats: Low Outlier Growth - Business sentiment index

key_trends: Strong economic performance is vital for industry success. As consumer sentiment grows and the economy strengthens, demand for hair salon servicing will increase.

Accelerating product innovation will help strengthen industry resilience. Since hair salons operate within a limited industry niche, improving product quality and expanding their service offering will enhance industry growth.

Emphasis on strong per capita disposable income growth is crucial for the industry. If consumers lack fiscal flexibility in affording these discretionary services, demand for many hair services will decline.

Diverse regulatory landscape fuels larger compliance costs for hair salons. Since most of the hair salons within the industry are small and localized, the wide variety of consumer and safety regulations enhances compliance costs.
Consistent consumer demand for traditional haircuts fuels revenue. Despite offering increasing luxury services that focus on looks, standard haircuts remain the core contributor for hair salons.

Activity among younger consumers is dependent on stable economic conditions. Since younger consumers lack large discretionary income, any large-scale economic volatility will dampen their propensity to consume more expensive salon services.

Industry presence is heightened in areas with a large population. The localized nature of the industry makes it necessary for a region to have large population centers where customer access is plentiful.

Proximity to global fashion companies strengthens the industry. For regions that house significant fashion companies needing hair styling services, industry establishments will benefit from a unique demand stream.

Emphasis on high quality of service drives strong competition. Hair salons that can offer high-quality hair services will be able to secure customers in the long term and maintain a competitive edge over local competitors.
At-home substitute care products will drive external competition. The COVID-19 pandemic significantly altered consumer behaviors, forcing hair salons to compete against at-home services.
No company owns more than a 5.0% share of the industry. Since hair salons operate on a localized basis and face notable operating costs, capturing a significant market share is difficult.
The industry's fragmented nature leads to low market concentration. Hair salons succeed when they secure a notable stream of customers and can market their services to them.

Industry profitability is dependent on stable economic conditions. If the economy performs poorly and consumer confidence drops, hair salons will suffer revenue losses as consumer demand will decline.

Constant necessity for qualified workers will drive high wage costs. Since haircuts and salon services cannot be automated, the industry will continue to invest a notable amount of capital in hiring qualified employees.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market segment is composed of revenue generated from the sales of hair salon services to consumers younger than 25 years old.
This market segment generates revenue from the sale of hair salon services to consumers between the ages of 25 to 34.
This market segment generates revenue from selling hair salon services to consumers between the ages of 35 and 44.
This market segment is composed of revenue generated from the sale of hair salon services and products to consumers between the ages of 45 to 54.
These market segments generate revenue from two groups of consumers; those aged 55 to 64 and those older than 65.
These market segments generate revenue from two groups of consumers; those aged 55 to 64 and those older than 65.

products_and_services.product_description: The haircutting and styling services segment is composed of revenue generated from the sales of haircut, hairstyle and hair maintenance services like shampooing, blow-drying and styling.
This product segment is composed of revenue from selling hair coloring services to customers.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Resale of Merchandise and Cosmetic Products
products_and_services.product_description: This product segment is composed of revenue generated from the resale of merchandise and cosmetic products direct to consumers.
The skincare services segment is composed of revenue generated from the sale of skincare services, like temporary makeup for clients, facial services and body-wrap services.

tier_2_suppliers: Drug, Cosmetic & Toiletry Wholesaling in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: PERFORMANCE FOR HAIRCUTTING AND STYLING SERVICES

demand_determinants.determinant_title: RECOVERY IN DISPOSABLE INCOME BOOSTS GROWTH FOR HAIR
DAMPENED ECONOMIC SENTIMENT CAUSES DECLINE IN THE
demand_determinants.determinant_description: RESALE OF MERCHANDISE AND COSMETIC PRODUCTS

demand_determinants.determinant_title: REBOUNDING CONSUMER DEMAND BOLSTERS DEMAND FOR SKINCARE SERVICES
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The skincare services segment is composed of revenue generated from the sale of skincare services, like temporary makeup for clients, facial services and body-wrap services.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: HIGHER DISPOSABLE INCOME ENHANCES DEMAND FOR HAIR TEXTURE MODIFICATION AND REMOVAL SERVICES TO DROP
demand_determinants.determinant_description: This product segment is composed of revenue generated from selling hair texture modification, hair styling and hair removal services to customers.

business_locations.location_description: With a rapidly expanding population and favorable climate, the Southeast secures the largest share of industry establishments across the United States.

The Mid-Atlantic continues to be an attractive hotspot for hair salons. Large population centers in states like New York providing industry establishments with a large pool of consumers they can target.
The Western region has many similarities with the Southeast as it relates to large population centers and warm weather, making it easier for customers to travel to hair salons.
Although the Great Lakes lack the warmer weather compared with other geographic regions, the presence of large urban centers in states like Illinois helped fuel industry growth.
The biggest advantage for industry establishments in the Southwest remains the consistently warm climate that enables consumers to travel more frequently for hair salon services.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Hair salons are subject to federal advertising and consumer protection laws, with the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) taking legal action against an industry servicer if its advertisements are misleading.

Federal regulations concerning the health and safety of employees and customers have a particularly strong influence on the Hair Salons industry. Formaldehyde is highly toxic to humans and can be present in hair salons due to its presence in some hair treatment products.

During the COVID-19 pandemic, industry servicers complied with additional health and safety mandates, including social distancing measures, personal protective equipment like face masks and gloves and capacity limits for establishments.
Most states require hairdressers to complete a program prior to receiving a license that permits them to work at a hair salon.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry's primary expense remains raw labor, with capital costs limited to the acquisition of products and tools for hair services.
The hair salons industry is a mature industry, which increases barriers to entry.

basis_points.basis_description: Emphasis on high quality of service drives strong competition. Hair salons that can offer high-quality hair services will be able to secure customers in the long term and maintain a competitive edge over local competitors.
At-home substitute care products will drive external competition. The COVID-19 pandemic significantly altered consumer behaviors, forcing hair salons to compete against at-home services.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Localized nature of the industry contributes to small establishment sizes and decentralized marketplace. Since hair salons are located in predominantly large population centers and service local clientele, it creates a decentralized market in which no single company can control a large stake in the market.
Hair salons are very fragmented, with many establishments operating with fewer than 5 employees and competing for consumer demand at the local level.

Dependence on broader economic stability discourages consolidation of market power. The Hair Salons Industry grows when there are stable economic conditions and consumers have strong disposable income levels.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: EMPHASIS ON CUSTOMER SERVICE CONTINUES TO DRIVE HIGH WAGE COSTS FOR HAIR SALONS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: One of the core expenditures for any hair salon is the cost of acquiring and maintaining qualified staff to operate the salon and provide high-level customer service.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: NOTEWORTHY ADMINISTRATIVE MAINTENANCE COSTS ENHANCE OPERATING EXPENSES FOR THE INDUSTRY
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Hair salon owners must also deal with various expenses like administrative costs, insurance policies, client consultation fees and maintenance of the physical establishment.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Continuous Need for Hair Products and Merchandise
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Maintains steady purchase costs for the industry.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry's primary expense remains raw labor, with capital costs limited to the acquisition of products and tools for hair services.

volatility_points.volatility_title: THE HAIR SALONS INDUSTRY ENDURES MODERATE VOLATILITY,
volatility_points.volatility_description: Although the industry was historically stable, recent economic volatility in light of the COVID-19 pandemic caused industry volatility to heighten.

FAQs.question: How much revenue does your salon earn through merchandise sales?
FAQs.answer: On average, a hair salon generates around 5.0% of revenue from the resale of merchandise.

FAQs.question: How has your salon diversified premium product offerings?
FAQs.answer: Hair salons are offering a greater array of premium products and services, including hair coloring and treatment services.

FAQs.question: Does your salon have wage costs under control?
FAQs.answer: Wages represent the largest operating cost for salons, accounting for 46.7% of revenue in 2023.

FAQs.question: What is your salon's target market?
FAQs.answer: Consumers aged 45-54 represent the largest market. On average, individuals in this group spend $97 more per year on personal care compared with consumers aged 35-44.

FAQs.question: How does your salon leverage new technology, such as mobile app booking, to streamline appointments and communication?
FAQs.answer: Consumers prefer to book appointments on their smartphones quickly and easily on apps like MyTime. During the COVID-19 pandemic hair salons have increasingly built new mobile applications.

FAQs.question: Does your salon leverage social media platforms, such as Instagram and Yelp, to establish a stronger market presence?
FAQs.answer: Influencers on social media, especially through reviews, are key to developing new marketing channels.

FAQs.question: How does your salon ensure all health safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) offers free consultations to small business employers to identify potential hazards at work sites.

FAQs.question: Is your company subject to any franchising laws?
FAQs.answer: There are specific laws pertinent to franchise-run companies that can impact operations.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors?
FAQs.answer: Profit for the average salon is an estimated 5.0% of total revenue.

FAQs.question: How do you keep operating costs down while still providing high levels of service?
FAQs.answer: Containing controllable costs is one way to maximize profitability.

FAQs.question: What do you do to promote loyalty and keep your customers returning? Do you offer special discounts or a high-caliber client experience?
FAQs.answer: A satisfied client base encourages repeat customers.

FAQs.question: How successful has your company been in matching the supply of its services to demand in the market?
FAQs.answer: It is critical to have experience and skills in managing and operating all aspects of a small business to achieve financial success.

FAQs.question: Is your location easily accessible? How many of your clients are walk-ins?
FAQs.answer: Salons benefit from walk-in clients and repeat customers.

FAQs.question: What services do customers tend to request when competition is high? How do you plan to mitigate the threat of rising competition?
FAQs.answer: The industry contends with external competition from drug stores, beauty and hair product retailers and spas.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor unemployment rates to plan your business accordingly? How will falling unemployment benefit your company?
FAQs.answer: When unemployment increases, clients are less likely to indulge in higher-value salon services.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of rising disposable income levels? How do you stimulate demand when disposable income is low?
FAQs.answer: When per capita disposable income rises, consumers are more likely to visit a hair salon.
